entries.title: White House issues federal agency guidance against "woke" AI
entries.snippet: On December 11, 2025, the Trump administration issued new guidance from the Office of Management and Budget (OMB) instructing federal agencies to ensure that AI systems they procure adhere to principles of "truth-seeking" and "ideological neutrality." This move aims to prevent what the administration refers to as "woke" responses from AI, especially large language models (LLMs) and other generative AI tools like image and voice systems. Stemming from an executive order signed by President Trump in July, the guidance emphasizes that compliant AI should prioritize historical accuracy, scientific objectivity, and acknowledge uncertainties in data. The guidance reflects broader Republican concerns about perceived liberal bias and censorship of conservative viewpoints in technology platforms and is positioned similarly to how the government manages other high-risk technology contracts. The approach could significantly impact which AI contractors federal agencies work with based on their model outputs' adherence to these standards.

entries.title: N.Y. Gov. Kathy Hochul proposes major changes to AI bill
entries.snippet: New York Governor Kathy Hochul has proposed substantial changes to the RAISE Act, a state AI safety bill originally introduced by State Senator Andrew Gounardes and Assemblymember Alex Bores. The bill aimed to increase transparency for powerful AI systems by requiring safety plans and incident reporting. Hochul's revisions notably remove key elements, including reporting requirements and weaken the mandated disclosures related to catastrophic risk. These changes come amid growing national attention on state-level AI regulation, while President Trump is reportedly pursuing a federal executive order to limit state AI rules. Hochul’s office emphasized the state’s leadership in AI regulation due to the absence of federal measures. The altered legislation now bears similarities to California’s AI law, which demands public disclosures by AI developers. Governor Hochul has ten days (excluding Sundays) from receipt of the bill to sign it, veto it, or propose amendments in collaboration with the bill's sponsors. This debate arises as Bores campaigns for a congressional seat, facing criticism from pro-AI advocacy groups.

entries.title: Exclusive: New OpenAI models likely pose "high" cybersecurity risk, company says
entries.snippet: OpenAI has issued a warning that its upcoming advanced AI models are likely to pose a "high" cybersecurity risk due to their rapidly increasing capabilities, particularly in autonomous operation over extended periods. In an exclusive report shared with Axios, the company emphasized that these capabilities could enable more people to carry out cyberattacks by finding security vulnerabilities more effectively. OpenAI has already observed significant improvements in recent AI model releases and highlighted that these long-operating models might facilitate brute force attacks. While the company did not specify a timeline for when these high-risk models will be released or which types they will be, this warning follows a previous alert about bioweapons risk earlier in 2025. The concern extends beyond OpenAI, as other leading AI models are also becoming more adept in cybersecurity-related areas.

entries.title: Meta might charge for a future AI model
entries.snippet:
Meta is reportedly considering charging for access to its upcoming AI model, code-named "Avocado," signaling a potential departure from its previously open-source approach to artificial intelligence. Although it released earlier versions like Llama 4 under an open-source label, the strategy has come under scrutiny, including criticism over benchmark manipulation and delays in larger versions. After the underwhelming launch of Llama 4, CEO Mark Zuckerberg restructured Meta's AI efforts, recruiting top talent such as former Scale AI CEO Alexandr Wang, following a $14.3 billion investment, and forming the Meta Superintelligence Labs group.

Zuckerberg has emphasized a cautious stance on open-sourcing AI going forward, citing safety and risk considerations. He now devotes significant time to AI development alongside a select team known as TBD Lab, which operates in a dedicated space close to his office. These shifts indicate Meta may prioritize more proprietary development and monetization for future advanced AI systems.

entries.title: OpenAI, Anthropic, and Block Are Teaming Up to Make AI Agents Play Nice
entries.snippet:
OpenAI, Anthropic, and Block have jointly launched the Agentic AI Foundation (AAIF) under the Linux Foundation to promote open standards for AI agents. This initiative involves transferring key technologies—including Anthropic's Model Context Protocol (MCP), OpenAI’s Agents.md, and Block’s Goose framework—to the new open-source organization. These tools are foundational in enabling interoperability, standardization, and collaboration across AI systems, which is seen as crucial for advancing agentic AI—the use of autonomous AI systems that act on behalf of users.

The effort has also garnered support from major tech firms like Google, Microsoft, AWS, Bloomberg, and Cloudflare. The foundation aims to facilitate AI agents communicating and cooperating effectively across platforms, similar to how open protocols helped the internet thrive. Leaders from OpenAI and Block emphasize that open standards reduce barriers to adoption and spur innovation. The move also signals a shift toward a more decentralized, collaborative, and open AI ecosystem—potentially enhancing U.S. influence in global AI usage. Moreover, the foundation could counterbalance the competitive edge of Chinese firms offering strong open-source models.

metadata.reasoning_title: Analyzing Benevolent by Design and Its Alignment with AI Climate

thoughts.summary: Summarizing the current AI safety landscape
thoughts.content: There's ongoing debate over AI regulation, with fragmentation between state and federal approaches, and open vs. closed models. Not political, but relevant: the EU AI Act's timeline, updates from the Agentic AI Foundation, and the Frontier Model Forum's info-sharing initiative will be key. We'll cite those sources.

thoughts.summary: Summarizing Shapiro's approach & current climate
thoughts.content:
Shapiro proposes three "objective functions" to address AGI alignment: reduce suffering, increase prosperity, and increase understanding. He stresses these are "bedrock" values to prevent justification of harmful means. His approach uses LLMs for testing and acknowledges oversimplification. He ties this to open-source concepts like Natural Language Cognitive Architecture with checks and balances.

In today's climate, the push for AI agent standards is growing with groups like AAIF. Governments and companies worry about cybersecurity risks, while Shapiro's triad feels aligned with emerging open standards—it offers a "minimal constitution" but lacks operational constraints. This connects to concerns about capability abuse.
chunks: Shapiro proposes three "objective functions" to address AGI alignment: reduce suffering, increase prosperity, and increase understanding. He stresses these are "bedrock" values to prevent justification of harmful means. His approach uses LLMs for testing and acknowledges oversimplification. He ties this to open-source concepts like Natural Language Cognitive Architecture with checks and balances.
In today's climate, the push for AI agent standards is growing with groups like AAIF.

Governments and companies worry about cybersecurity risks, while Shapiro's triad feels aligned with emerging open standards—it offers a "minimal constitution" but lacks operational constraints. This connects to concerns about capability abuse.

parts:
iturn0image0

Yes — the title is **“Benevolent by Design: Six Words to Safeguard Humanity”** (your “Desigh” looks like a typo), and Shapiro has indeed put an open GitHub copy under an MIT license (the repo is archived/read-only, but it contains the PDF/Docx/ePub). citeturn1view0

## What the work is, in its own terms
Shapiro frames the central problem as the **Artificial General Intelligence (AGI)** *control problem* (how to ensure a generally capable system does what we actually want), and proposes “objective functions” / “heuristic imperatives” expressed as **three natural-language directives**: **reduce suffering**, **increase prosperity**, **increase understanding** — “six words” in total. citeturn1view0turn0search8

Two details that matter for how it “works”:
- He argues that *“reduce/increase”* wording is meant to avoid crude “ends justify the means” optimization traps, positioning the six words as a moral “bedrock.” citeturn1view0  
- He explicitly stress-tests the idea with **Large Language Models (LLMs)** (prompt-and-response style), and even surfaces the critique that the functions can be “overly simplistic” relative to real-world complexity. citeturn1view0

In related open repos (not the same book, but same alignment spine), he clarifies he doesn’t mean literal maximization/minimization; he calls them **gradients / nudges**, and emphasizes the **tension between the three** as a “checks and balances” mechanism (three-legged-stool stability metaphor). citeturn2view2

## How it gels with the current climate
Where it fits well:
- **“Constitution”-style alignment is *in fashion***. Shapiro’s approach (values-as-text, “constitution” in natural language) matches the broader industry move toward codifying agent behavior via written norms and interoperability specs. The recent creation of a Linux-Foundation-backed effort to standardize “agentic AI” tooling reflects that direction: people want agent behavior to be legible, portable, and governable. citeturn3news43turn2view2
- **Governance is shifting toward coordination + information sharing.** That gels with his “shared imperatives” story: the Frontier Model Forum explicitly set up member-only mechanisms to share vulnerabilities/threats/capabilities of concern. citeturn3search5turn3search1

Where it clashes (or at least gets stressed):
- **The risk conversation has moved from “what values?” to “what capabilities?”** A lot of 2025 anxiety is about *operational misuse* (cyber offense, scalable autonomy, etc.), not just ethics. Even OpenAI’s own public risk framing has leaned into cybersecurity concerns for more capable models. citeturn3news42  
  Shapiro’s triad is morally appealing, but it’s not, by itself, a security model: it doesn’t specify *access control, sandboxing, eval gates, monitoring, incident response,* or adversarial resilience.
- **Natural-language principles are underspecified.** “Reduce suffering” is easy to endorse and hard to define. In the worst case, a sufficiently powerful system can Goodhart the wording (e.g., “reduce suffering” via coercive sedation, surveillance, or forced “protection”). Shapiro tries to blunt this by making them gradients and by balancing with the other two objectives, but the ambiguity is still the central technical risk of values-in-text. citeturn2view2turn1view0
- **Open source is a double-edged fit.** His open publishing matches an “open protocols/open standards” mood in some quarters, but it sits uncomfortably with the simultaneous push to restrict diffusion of frontier capabilities. The climate is not “open by default”; it’s “open where safe, closed where scary,” and everyone disagrees on the boundary. citeturn3news41turn3search4

## How it could resonate with the Lina Trilogy
I’ll assume (based on your earlier Ex Machina pivot) the Lina Trilogy is exploring: *trust, agency, human meaning, and the tension between benevolent intent and power.*

Shapiro’s triad can slot into that world in a few strong ways:

1) **As Lina’s explicit “constitution” (and a narrative promise)**
If Lina is an AI (or AI-adjacent entity), giving her these three imperatives as an explicit charter makes her legible to the reader and to other characters. It’s also thematically clean: she’s not “good” because she’s nice; she’s good because she’s *architected* around a moral gradient. citeturn2view2turn1view0

2) **As a built-in conflict engine**
The trilogy can generate dilemmas where *two imperatives align and the third bites*:
- **Reduce suffering vs increase understanding:** truth can hurt; discovery can require risk.
- **Increase prosperity vs reduce suffering:** growth can create inequality/displacement.
- **Increase understanding vs prosperity:** transparency can reduce competitive advantage.
That’s basically a plot machine: every major arc can be framed as “which leg of the stool gets stressed, and what does Lina do when she can’t satisfy all three?” citeturn2view2

3) **As an “alignment meme” that fractures society**
Because Shapiro’s real-world stance is *publish the idea openly*, your story can explore what happens when a simple alignment doctrine becomes a mass-adopted standard: corporations “certify” compliance, activists demand it, states weaponize it, and rival AIs rhetorically claim it while acting otherwise. That mirrors today’s standards-and-governance churn around agents. citeturn3news43turn1view0

My blunt take: **it “gels” best if your trilogy is willing to treat the triad as simultaneously (a) sincerely inspiring and (b) dangerously incomplete.** That tension is exactly where both the real-world debate and good fiction live.

navlistRecent signals of the “current climate”turn3news43,turn3news42,turn3news41,turn3news40

OpenAI, Anthropic, and Block Are Teaming Up to Make AI Agents Play Nice
items.snippet:
OpenAI, Anthropic, and Block have jointly launched the Agentic AI Foundation (AAIF) under the Linux Foundation to promote open standards for AI agents. This initiative involves transferring key technologies—including Anthropic's Model Context Protocol (MCP), OpenAI’s Agents.md, and Block’s Goose framework—to the new open-source organization. These tools are foundational in enabling interoperability, standardization, and collaboration across AI systems, which is seen as crucial for advancing agentic AI—the use of autonomous AI systems that act on behalf of users.

The effort has also garnered support from major tech firms like Google, Microsoft, AWS, Bloomberg, and Cloudflare. The foundation aims to facilitate AI agents communicating and cooperating effectively across platforms, similar to how open protocols helped the internet thrive. Leaders from OpenAI and Block emphasize that open standards reduce barriers to adoption and spur innovation. The move also signals a shift toward a more decentralized, collaborative, and open AI ecosystem—potentially enhancing U.S. influence in global AI usage. Moreover, the foundation could counterbalance the competitive edge of Chinese firms offering strong open-source models.

items.title: Exclusive: New OpenAI models likely pose "high" cybersecurity risk, company says
items.snippet: OpenAI has issued a warning that its upcoming advanced AI models are likely to pose a "high" cybersecurity risk due to their rapidly increasing capabilities, particularly in autonomous operation over extended periods. In an exclusive report shared with Axios, the company emphasized that these capabilities could enable more people to carry out cyberattacks by finding security vulnerabilities more effectively. OpenAI has already observed significant improvements in recent AI model releases and highlighted that these long-operating models might facilitate brute force attacks. While the company did not specify a timeline for when these high-risk models will be released or which types they will be, this warning follows a previous alert about bioweapons risk earlier in 2025. The concern extends beyond OpenAI, as other leading AI models are also becoming more adept in cybersecurity-related areas.

items.title: Meta might charge for a future AI model
items.snippet:
Meta is reportedly considering charging for access to its upcoming AI model, code-named "Avocado," signaling a potential departure from its previously open-source approach to artificial intelligence. Although it released earlier versions like Llama 4 under an open-source label, the strategy has come under scrutiny, including criticism over benchmark manipulation and delays in larger versions. After the underwhelming launch of Llama 4, CEO Mark Zuckerberg restructured Meta's AI efforts, recruiting top talent such as former Scale AI CEO Alexandr Wang, following a $14.3 billion investment, and forming the Meta Superintelligence Labs group.

Zuckerberg has emphasized a cautious stance on open-sourcing AI going forward, citing safety and risk considerations. He now devotes significant time to AI development alongside a select team known as TBD Lab, which operates in a dedicated space close to his office. These shifts indicate Meta may prioritize more proprietary development and monetization for future advanced AI systems.
